Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Tahu goreng" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(February 2013)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Tahu goreng** ([Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language) spelling) or **tauhu goreng** (Bruneian, Malaysian and Singaporean spelling) is a generic name for any type of fried [tofu](/wiki/Tofu) dish in the cuisines of [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine), [Brunei](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine). ## Preparation When preparing the dish, cakes of hard [tofu](/wiki/Tofu) are deep-fried until golden brown. A popular way to serve fried tofu is to cut them diagonally in half and arrange on a plate garnished with [bean sprouts](/wiki/Bean_sprout), [cucumber](/wiki/Cucumber), and [scallion](/wiki/Scallion). A thick sauce is prepared with [shallots](/wiki/Shallot), [garlic](/wiki/Garlic), [chili peppers](/wiki/Chili_pepper), [shrimp paste](/wiki/Shrimp_paste), [soy sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce), and [tamarind](/wiki/Tamarind) juice. ## Cultural origins In [Malay language](/wiki/Malay_language) and [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language), *tauhu* or *tahu* refers to 'tofu' and *goreng* indicates 'fried'. Tofu originated from [China](/wiki/China) and was brought to [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia) by Chinese immigrants to the region. Its first arrival in Indonesia is estimated through the [Khubilai Khan](/wiki/Kublai_Khan)'s army in Kediri in 1292. ## Variations ### Indonesia In Indonesia, tahu goreng can be mildly fried or deep fried, plain or [battered](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)). In Indonesia, tahu goreng is usually eaten with *sambal kecap* a kind of [sambal](/wiki/Sambal) hot condiment made from *[kecap manis](/wiki/Kecap_manis)* (sweet soy sauce) and chopped [chili peppers](/wiki/Chili_pepper) and shallots. Some variants might use [peanut sauce](/wiki/Peanut_sauce) with chili instead. Some variants are: - **Tahu isi**: (lit: filled tofu), probably the most popular variant of tahu goreng in Indonesia, is tofu filled with [bean sprouts](/wiki/Bean_sprout), [carrots](/wiki/Carrot) and sometimes minced meat is battered and deep fried. It is commonly found sold by [gorengan](/wiki/Gorengan) (Indonesian fritters) vendors. Commonly eaten with *cabai rawit* ([bird's eye chili](/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chili)). - **[Tahu sumedang](/wiki/Tahu_sumedang)**: the name derived from [Sumedang](/wiki/Sumedang) city, [West Java](/wiki/West_Java). Pioneered by the Tahu Bunkeng tofu store in Sumedang established by Chinese immigrants in 1917. - **[Tahu gejrot](/wiki/Tahu_gejrot)**: fried tofu in a thin, hot, sweet, and sour sauce with shallots and chilies, originated from [Cirebon](/wiki/Cirebon) City, [West Java](/wiki/West_Java). - **Tahu taoge**: stir-fried diced tofu with beansprouts. - **[Tahu campur](/wiki/Tahu_campur)**: (lit: mixed tofu), with beef slices, vegetables, beansprouts, and noodles or rice vermicelli, served in thin broth. The dish is common in [East Javan](/wiki/East_Java) cities, such as [Malang](/wiki/Malang), [Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya), and [Lamongan](/wiki/Lamongan). - **Tahu gunting**: (lit: tofu cut with scissors), fried tofu in thick sweet and spicy peanut sauce, originated from [Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya) city, [East Java](/wiki/East_Java). - **Tahu telur**: (lit: tofu with egg), with [omelette](/wiki/Omelette), beansprout, peanuts, and [lontong](/wiki/Lontong) rice cake, served in thin sweet and sour soy sauce. Also originated from [Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya) City, [East Java](/wiki/East_Java). - **Tahu bulat** (round tofu) or **tahu bola** also called **bola-bola tahu** (tofu balls): is a relatively new variant of fried tofu from [Tasikmalaya](/wiki/Tasikmalaya). The tofu is mixed with seasoning and shaped in balls or rounded form, and later deep-fried in cooking oil. - **[Kupat tahu](/wiki/Kupat_tahu)**: (lit: [ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat) with tofu), [ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat) rice cake, beansprout, served in thick sweet and spicy peanut sauce, common throughout Java, however the most popular variant came from [Kuningan](/wiki/Kuningan_Regency), Magelang, Solo, and Surabaya. - Food portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - [Batagor](/wiki/Batagor) - [Yong tau foo](/wiki/Yong_tau_foo) - [List of tofu dishes](/wiki/List_of_tofu_dishes) - [List of deep-fried foods](/wiki/List_of_deep-fried_foods) - [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) - [Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Singaporean cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - Indonesian stuffed tofu (*tahu isi*) recipe from [SBS Australia](/wiki/SBS_Australia)
title: Tahu goreng
